content.description:
Climb the right side of the face on good edges. The best problem on the boulder.

Good spot to warm up at Kelly's Hill. Book lists two other problems (Face, left and Face, center) on this boulder, but I found them to be a bit contrived...hard to not trend toward the right at some point to the better holds and cleaner rock. Either way, it's nice to do a few laps on different variations as part of the warm up program.
content.location: The "Face Boulder" is the first boulder you come to when hiking up to Kelly's Hill from the main trail/trailhead. Routes #1-3 (all named "Face") in the Bob Banks guidebook are on this boulder. See the guidebook for a good map.

content.description: Same start as Emergency Response, but slap directly up and left to (you guessed it) a slopey topout. Only about two moves, but the rock is good and the moves are worthy.
content.protection: Crash pad if it's handy, or none.
content.location: On the Johnny Bigmouth boulder, left of the boulder's namesake climb.

content.description: Another fun 2-move wonder. Right hand on the hold at the bottom of the left-trending weakness and, no surprises here, jump start on up to the left hand hold at the top of the weakness. One more move to the topout jugs.
content.protection: Crash pad if it's handy, or none.
content.location: At the main area of Kelly's Hill, on the boulder immediately to the left of the trail. See the Bob Banks book for a nice map.

content.description: Sit start on great holds in the low hueco on the overhanging tallest part of the boulder. I went pretty much straight up on slopers, most of which have a little bit of a positive edge. Guidebook says to go up and right. Either way, getting established out of the hole is probably the crux.
content.location: This problem is in the "main area" of Kelly's Hill. When hiking up to this area from the main trail, you'll see the boulder with Jump Start on your left and the obvious striking prow of the Johnnie Big Mouth boulder on your right. Good map in the Bob Banks book.

content.description: Sit start on holds at the bottom of the hole, move into sandy undercling (crux), reach for the top. Or, start in the undercling for a one-move V0.
content.location: On the Jump Start boulder, starting from the big hole that faces the trail.

content.description: Looks pretty short and silly but is actually quite fun. Start on the big chalked ledge, do a move or two out right, then slap up to the top and mantel. Fairly typical slopey mantel topout crux.
content.protection: Crash pad if it's handy, or none.
content.location: Located on the Johnny Bigmouth boulder, left of the boulder's namesake route.

content.description: Located just to the left of Johnny Big Mouth. Start left hand on upper hueco and right on sloppy side pull. Make big move to get both hands on two separate slopers and finish up and slightly to the right.
A really cool overhanging crack with a variety of jams. The further underneath you start the harder it is.
content.protection: Couple of pads should be sufficient
content.location: This problem is a bit tricky to find, from Johnny Bigmouth then it is about thirty feet to the right in a small boulder cave.
